Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: This course provided an overview of fish biology and ecology, as well as the role fish play in our lives and our roles in their lives. It was very interesting and very interdisciplinary.
I learned a lot about fish and how most of tetrapod evolution can be traced back to these fantastic aquatic creatures.
I learned a deep understanding about fish taxonomy and diversity!
I learned a lot about fish!
I learned a lot about fish anatomy, ecology, economics (fisheries), and the evolutionary importance of fish (tetrapodization). Also was exposed to a great amount of fish diversity in this course
Drastic improvement in my ability to recognize fish and by the end a mild understanding of the tools that fish regularly use to survive.

The strength of this course was in its emphasis on the interdisciplinary nature of fish. Also, it was great at exposing us to fish diversity and the "so what?" of ichthyology as a field. The only weakness was that the course felt a bit redundant at times, and we didn't learn about nearly as many explicit kinds of fish as I was hoping to.

Professor Harrington's lecture style and slides were definitely a highlight  never before have I seen such engaging slides (especially in a science course). One weakness of the course may lie in the overall structure and organization  it seemed like the teleost fishes were skimmed over at the end of the course.
This class could be improved for students that aren't already familiar with evolutionary biology. A vocabulary list or something like that would have been helpful.
Very interesting and engaging course. Both material and instructor were great!

Lectures were engaging, the use of videos and other visual aids was enhancing and not distracting. Dr. Harrington is an engaging lecturer who is clearly passionate about his field and passes on that excitement to the students

Strengths: Professor Harrington for sure, he was brilliant and fun and captivating. 
Greatest strength of the class was that it was super fun to go to and overall very enjoyable. 

Powerpoint slides were sometimes confusing, when going back to study for the test there was so much information and I had trouble distinguishing names of families and species, etc.

I drastically preferred the portions of the course that focused on extant species, as well as extinct species that seemed relevant to organ systems development. It would be nice if the class focused a bit more on a topic opposed to being as spread out.
I really enjoyed the course. While you do need to know the material in depth for the exams, the course was overall pretty low-stress, and fish are actually really interesting!

I would most definitely recommend this course. It has been one of my favorite courses at Yale. Rich was great at facilitating a community and making the course engaging. Also, the course is very interdisciplinary, the most interdisciplinary of all the organismal diversity courses, and thus has appeal for STEM and non-STEM majors alike.

Yes! Ichthyology is super fun (the videos are awesome) and Professor Harrington's love for fish is contagious. With only three midterms, a quiz, and a short paper, the workload isn't too bad, as well.
Yes, it was a lot of fun
Yes definitely! If you're interested in fish, take it. If you need a science credit, take it. If you just wanna take a fun class, take it.
Yes, I think it's a well taught, relatively straightforward course that does exactly what it promises. Prof. Harrington is perfect for the role and it was an enjoyable experience.
Yes - take it, it's fun and if you have any interest in snorkeling, fishing, or the ocean this is a great class to take.
I would highly recommend this class, it was extremely fun and interesting, and Professor Harrington is definitely my favorite professor that I have encountered in my time at Yale.

Take this course if you have the time. This class made me excited about fish, which I really wasn't expecting when I enrolled. I had never been fishing before, nor had I any knowledge related to fish prior to this course, but at this point studying more ichthyology sounds pretty nice.
